ADRIAN PIPER, MAKING BLACK LIVES MATTER BEFORE ‘BLACK LIVES MATTER’

THE WEEKLY PIC: Every so often, an artist manages to pinpoint the issues that are central to a culture before most people realize they are even on the table. Adrian Piper is one of those artists. Her current retrospective at MoMA – as the first living artist to occupy the museum’s whole top floor – feels like a product of our Black Lives Matter moment, even though many of its works were made decades ago.  More than anything, Piper captures the complexity of race relations in the United States and contrasts that with the simpleminded binaries that many of us use to address them. There’s something terribly poignant about a picture, like today’s Pic, that feels a need to remind its viewers of the normal place of black people in the American mix, and how many different roles they can inhabit. The need for the reminder underlines how little is “normal” about the place that’s been made for them.

My photo is one of four from a 1990 work called Safe, whose name makes our abnormality even more evident. Can you imagine needing to affix such a title to a photo of Norwegian Americans? But let’s be clear here: Piper isn’t in the business of reassuring un-Black Americans that Blacks are not a threat. She’s calling out American culture for wanting the reassurance. (Collection Adrian Piper Research Archive Foundation Berlin, ©Adrian Piper Research Archive Foundation Berlin)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: Is it possible to make “high” art that raises the status of “low” art – of functional objects like quilts and textiles and such? Or does the high, in its effort to elevate, always end up condescending to the (supposedly) low? When you put a functional object into an art museum, are you doing it a favor or are you saying that it’s only worthwhile once it has an art institution’s imprimatur? There’s a convincing philosophical argument that says that something gets to count as art because the art world decides that’s what it is – and if that’s right, are we then doing violence to functional non-art by making that decision? After all, once Duchamp’s urinal became a sculpture called “Fountain,” you couldn’t pee in it anymore.

All of those issues are very much in play at the Museum of Arts and Design – always, but especially in the fascinating current show called “Surface/Depth: The Decorative After Miriam Schapiro.” Schapiro, and many of the more recent artists who have taken off from her pioneering work in the 1970s and 80s, riff on the “women’s work” sewn over the years by humble (and not so humble) craftspeople. But the very act of these artists’ appropriation might imply that crafts only gain true worth once they’ve become art.

Don’t get me wrong: I’m crazy about art that takes craftiness as its subject. That often makes it better art, as Schapiro’s work proves.

The question I can’t answer is, does that make it worse craft?

(My image shows Miriam Schapiro’s Connection (1978), made from found embroidered handkerchiefs and posted courtesy the University of Iowa Museum of Art; © 2018 Estate of Miriam Schapiro / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: I saw this big painting earlier this spring at the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar College, in Poughkeepsie, New York, and was surprised to find myself falling in love with it. It was painted around 1540 by Lambert Sustris, a Dutchman who worked in Venice, and represents an ultra-obscure allegorical subject called  “The Circle of False Education,” taken from an ultra-obscure late-classical text called the Tabula Cebetis. What’s not to not like about all that – except for the fact that, visually, I find the whole painting totally charming. Although the subject couldn’t be more bookish and dry, it can’t stop Sustris from taking vast pleasure in how things look, in the world but also in art.

Sustris is always mentioned as some kind of follower of Titian,  but could it be that my hero Andrea Schiavone was a more notable influence? For a long time the painting was actually attributed to Schiavone, because like Sustris, he often failed at the orderly rendering of human bodies, that ultimate Renaissance value. The great thing is that neither he nor Sustris seemed to mind their failure. As my other hero believed, failure is usually more compelling than success.

posts.caption:
WANDA KOOP’S DANGEROUS PAINTINGS

THE WEEKLY PIC: For a couple of decades, Wanda Koop has been one of Canada’s most respected painters, but she’s only now getting a solo show in New York, at Arsenal gallery on The Bowery.

This recent canvas, titled “Spill-Orange,” highlights (literally – look at it) the way that painting in Canada has a more vexed, complex – and therefore interesting – status in market-unfriendly Canada than it does here in New York, with its endless appetite for pigment on canvas.  (“New York,” said a lapsed-painter friend, “treats painting like cake decorating.”)

With it’s two gorgeously caustic drips, the same color as the tailing pools from mines (as per photos by Edward Burtynsky, another Canuck), Koop’s “Spill-Orange” rejoices in the power of paint to seduce but also calls it into question. Paint is, after all, as industrial a product as any, so it works pretty well as a synechdoche for the effect of humans on the natural world – the way we drip down across the landscape, leaving a colorful but deadly trace. (Courtesy ARSENAL contemporary, NY)

posts.caption:
SO WARHOL DID NOT STEAL HIS ‘15 MINUTES’ LINE, AFTER ALL

THE WEEKLY PIC: There’s so much meat in Warhol’s Working Class, the recent book by University of Vermont scholar Anthony Grudin, that you could easily miss one of its more delicious tidbits. In the middle of Grudin’s landmark discussion of Warhol and branding he casually drops a mention of the very earliest ­– and I think  hitherto unknown ­– sighting of the artist’s line about “fifteen minutes of fame.” 

It comes from a 1965 article about the curator Henry Geldzahler, which quotes Warhol as saying, “There’s going to be a day when no one will be famous for more than a week. Then everyone will have a chance to be famous.”  It’s not the classic form of Warhol’s line, maybe, but the content is all there, at least in embryo. Now the question is, did he later add the minute-count himself or was it added by other writers who were elaborating on Warhol’s original concept? Either way, thanks to Grudin I now have to give up on my cherished (and much trumpeted) claim that the whole fleeting-fame idea didn’t begin with Warhol.

I admit that none of that matters nearly as much as the truly big concepts and discoveries that Grudin explores in his book.

One is that the venerable brands that Warhol riffed on, including Campbell’s and Coke, were being newly marketed to the working class at just the moment that Pop Art was born. (The elites had started to abandon branded products for generic groceries.) That means the subjects Warhol chose for his art had certain class connotations that have mostly been ignored until now.

Another is that this same working class was being targeted as potential buyers of drawing aids ­– projectors and the like ­– that were also used by Warhol to make his art. As Grudin points out, this means that class issues also informed Warhol’s technique and style.

What Grudin doesn’t fully weigh-in on is whether Warhol’s art is mostly made in sympathy with the workers who corporations were so keen on fleecing, or if it also has some complicity with the fleecers.

Like all the smartest Warholians, Grudin realizes that Warhol’s true art lay in achieving an unlikely balance between the two readings.

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: This is a small detail from an installation shot of “You See I Am Here After All,” one of Zoe Leonard’s agglomerations of old postcards of Niagara Falls (this one has 3,851 cards) which are standouts in her retrospective at the Whitney Museum in New York.

They are all about a pre-digital moment in our production and consumption of images. Looking at them, however, I was suddently struck by how much Leonard must have depended on digital culture (eBay etc.) to collect so many near-identical vintage cards.

I once argued that Ansel Adams’s images of machine-free nature were in fact about the modern technologies ­– of cars and cameras and darkrooms – that allowed them to happen. Could it be that many works of art, including Leonard’s postcard-piles, are more about what’s left out than what’s included? (Collection of the artist, courtesy Galerie Gisela Capitain, Cologne; photo by Bill Jacobson, New York)

posts.caption:
Leon Golub Should Have Lived to Paint Trump

THE WEEKLY PIC: One of the sad truths of our times is that the grimly political paintings of Leon Golub are looking more and more timely, as proven by the small survey of his work now at the Breuer building of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York. This 1977 painting of General Ernesto Geisel, then the dictatorial president of Brazil, seems a perfect depiction either:

a) of the banal faces that evil assumes

b) of the way an evil soul always reveals itself

Or maybe what it really proves is that an art object only attains meaning in the context of an artist’s entire body of work. At the Met Breuer, Geisel’s evil is proven by the company he keeps: oppressors of every stripe, at every level of society and all, I hate to point out, male. Donald Trump would look right at home among them. Too bad Golub died before he could add our president to his rogue’s gallery. (Metropolitan Museum of Art, intended Gift of Jon Bird, 2017; © The Nancy Spero and Leon Golub Foundation for the Arts/Licensed by VAGA, New York, NY)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: There are lots of potent works in the latest iteration of MoMA’s photography survey, this time titled “Being: New Photography 2018.” But none of them can compete with Carmen Winant’s vast agglomeration of  photos of women giving birth, clipped from every kind of published source, from just about every era, and then taped up on MoMA’s walls. Sometimes, nothing can beat the simple act of pointing out what’s most noteworthy in the world. (Click on my image to zoom in.)

Winant’s piece adds a nice and peculiar tension to its pointing: A vast accumulation of images of the single most important – literally defining – moment in each of our lives also points to how it’s the one moment that is most rarely represented. Winant depicts what a wall of random photo-clippings ought to look like, just about, and shows how in fact it takes some work to find such clip-ables in our culture.

The truth is, a wall of birth shots ought to be anything but rare or remarkable or particularly potent. The potency of Winant’s piece comes from the fact that it ought not to strike us at all. (Detail from “My Birth“ (2018), © 2018 Carmen Winant, photo by Martin Seck)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: The Andy Warhol we all know (and sometimes love) was born much later than we think. He didn’t perfect his cool-cat-in-leather routine until well into 1966; before that he’d often been closer to a cuddly Raggedy Andy.

The edgy image that still clings most closely to him really came about, as much as anything, because of the absurd popularity of his movie called “The Chelsea Girls,” which hit New York theaters in September of 1966 and spent the next two years amazing and appalling Americans across the nation. Its almost four hours of footage, projected across two screens at once, show Warhol’s motley crew shooting up, cavorting in bed, fighting and screaming and misbehaving in almost every imaginable way. Warhol was happy to see the sharp elbows and angles of his so-called Superstars cross over, in the popular imagination, into his more milquetoast persona.

“The Chelsea Girls” really is as close as Warhol came to a magnum opus, and yet it is so challenging – especially as compared to his Soup Cans and Marilyns – that for quite a while it hasn’t got the attention it deserves. I think attention will now be paid with the publication of a book called “Andy Warhol’s ‘The Chelsea Girls,’” to be released later this month by the Andy Warhol Museum in Pittsburgh and D.A.P. It includes transcripts of the full dialogue of the film as distributed, plus the dialogue from many reels that didn’t make it into the final version. (Given the film’s almost inaudible sound, whoever did the transcribing deserves a medal.) The book also reprints a nice sampling of the movie’s original reviews, both raves and rants.

“Andy Warhol’s ‘The Chelsea Girls,’” helps overcome the real challenges of watching the film. I’ve seen it three times over the last few years, and still don’t feel I’ve got a full grasp of it. The book gives a whole bunch of new handholds. (Image ©2017 The Andy Warhol Museum, Pittsburgh, PA, a museum of Carnegie Institute. All rights reserved. Film still courtesy The Andy Warhol Museum)

around 2,500 years ago by the Cupisnique/Chavín culture of...
posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: This cat-inspired piece of jewelry was made around 2,500 years ago by the Cupisnique/Chavín culture of present-day Peru, and was meant to hang down from the nose and cover the entire mouth. It’s in “Golden Kingdoms: Luxury and Legacy in the Ancient Americas,” at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York, and does a pretty good job of conveying the profound strangeness of so many of the objects in the Met show – strange, at least, to European eyes like mine.

I must say that I’ve never before come across works of art that had so little in common with the European esthetics I was raised and trained in, or even with the Asian ones I’ve come to know (a bit) over my years as a critic. The Pre-Hispanic cultures now on display at the Met, which span thousands of years and thousands of miles of territory, seemed to have utterly unique ideas about how an object should look and be made.

Here’s a guess I came up with for why that might be so. (And I’m happy to be corrected by any anthropologists in the room.) Looking at the objects, it felt to me as though the animal-centered theologies and ontologies of many of these cultures might have led to a profound distrust and even scorn for the mere human bodies that our species has been stuck with.

Instead of building a visual culture around a fundamental respect for human bodies and natures, the way Europeans and many Asian groups have, were Pre-Hispanic civilizations more interested in honoring the better-than-human by distorting and disguising human-ness in their art? (See for example the Paracas textile from ancient Peru, below.) If you truly believe that cat-gods or spider-spirits have all the answers, wouldn’t you want to do your best to conceal and disrupt your meager two-legged-ness?  Sounds more rational than strange to me. 

(Mouth mask courtesy Museo Kuntur Wasi, San Pablo, Ministerio de  Cultura del Perú, image © Kuntur Wasi Museum; detail of textile image © 2017 Museum of Fine Arts, Boston)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: This is a shot of a video installation called “If and Only If,” in the Marian Goodman Gallery’s latest Anri Sala show. Sala is the wonderful Albanian-born artist whose solo at the New Museum was a highlight of the 2016 season in New York. (Click on the image to watch my short clip.)

For the new work at Goodman, Sala has enlisted the musician Gérard Caussé to play Igor Stravinsky’s “Elegy for Solo Viola.’ He has also enlisted a snail (name unknown) to climb Caussé’s bow as he plays. The sleek video footage that results reads as somewhere between a promo for a fancy classical recording and an extract from a new episode of the BBC’s “Planet Earth.”

That tension between nurture and nature, culture and biology, is beautifully captured in the piece.

Is the snail obstacle or inspiration? Its presence acts as a break on Stravinsky’s piece, making Caussé stretch it out to double its normal duration. On the other hand, the press release says that the beast’s hesitant progress up the bow causes the musician to adapt his playing “to encourage the snail to carry on,” as though the two of them are cultural collaborators – which I guess they’ve become, thanks to Sala’s video. That “collaboration” between Caussé and Monsieur Escargot could also be read as conflict: The violist is playing games with the snail while the snail is busy sliming his fancy bow.

More than anything, I think If and Only If is about the profound gap that exists between humans and animals – not collaboration or conflict but utter and mutual incomprehension. The music, supposed to sooth the savage breast, probably means precisely nothing to the savage breast at hand. THE WEEKLY PIC: Kiki Kogelnik was an Austrian-born semi-Pop artist who, from the early ’60s on, hung out with many of the big (male) names of the New York art scene. What makes her art different from theirs is the way Kogelnick often introduces a subtle but palpable sense of a threatened female body.

Today’s Pic is a piece from the Kogelnik show that opened last weekend at Simone Subal Gallery in New York, under the title “Fragments and Masks: Works from the 70s and 80s.”

The cut-out shape of the picture makes its female protagonist resemble a knife, with all the agency that implies. Or that same shape, read as negative space, might also give the sense that the woman, with her pouting mouth and liquid eyes, is peeking through a mane of hair worthy of a Hollywood starlet; below her face, the “blade” of the knife might be the flesh left visible by the décolleté of a red-carpet gown. Instead of the duck-rabbit illusion Kogelnik gives us weapon-victim.

Maybe the figure’s not wielding that knife, after all. Maybe the “knife” stands for the threat that every woman knows she faces as she navigates our world.

(Image ©Kiki Kogelnik Foundation, all rights reserved, courtesy Simone Subal Gallery)

posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: Is it possible that the spark that the school shooter struck the other week among the students of Stoneman Douglas High will kindle a real conflagration of protest among the young? The show called “You Say You Want a Revolution: Remembering the 60s,” now at the New York Public Library, gives a stirring account of the last time such a protest movement happened, and I’m not sure there’s any reason it couldn’t happen again. If we’re not seeing all that much sign of it yet, remember that in 1964, the year of “I Want to Hold Your Hand,” few would have predicted that young people would be singing “War – what is it good for” a half-decade later.

One of the side benefits of the ’60s protest movement was that its sheer urgency created art with real heft, not just in music but also in visual art. My Pic for today is a poster from 1970 by Jay Belloli, on view at NYPL, and it certainly gets its message across – especially as compared to the wan pseudo- or semi-politics now on view in the New Museum triennial called “Songs for Sabotage.” (If that show represents sabotage, I’d hate to see what capitulation looks like.)

Of course, it doesn’t hurt that Belloli had an image by Francisco de Goya to lean on. Maybe the anti-democratic depredations of Donald Trump will spur a new Goya to arise among us.

posts.caption:
WAITING FOR A FLIGHT THAT’S RUNNING TEN YEARS LATE

THE WEEKLY PIC: This is a still from Naeem Mohaiemen’s video called “Tripoli Cancelled,” now installed at PS1 in New York. It is feature-length, and has feature-quality production values, but is distinctly un-featury in style and content. Its Muslim main character is shown stranded – for the last ten years, we gather – at an abandoned modernist airport in Athens. That’s the same airport that was turned into a temporary home for all of the asylum seekers from the Middle East who have washed up, often literally, on Greek shores over recent years.

“Tripoli Cancelled” could hardly be more topical. It touches on the fading of grand modernist dreams (and buildings), on the Greek and migrant crises and all the strandings they have created – spiritual strandings as much as literal ones.

And yet the piece doesn’t feel particularly negative. Despite his absurd predicament, the main character seems determined to carry on and deal with whatever fate chooses to dish out to him. He has an espresso pot for company, which is about as much as anyone can ask for these days. (© 2017 Naeem Mohaiemen, courtesy the artist and Experimenter, Kolkata)

posts.caption:
GORDON MATTA-CLARK, A HANDS-ON ARCHITECT

THE WEEKLY PIC: If the idea of the artist’s “hand” is one of art’s worst clichés, it’s a notion that’s almost totally missing from modern architecture and design. Buildings and domestic objects are almost always fully planned first then executed in the coldest, most impassive, most distanced way.

A rare recent exception: Martino Gamper’s “100 Chairs” project.

An older one: The architectural interventions of Gordon Matta-Clark, which are the subject of a show now at the Bronx Museum, which sits in a neighborhood where Matta-Clark did some early projects. (None are really “late,” since he died of cancer at 35, in 1978.)

Matta-Clark used the hands-on ideas of classic expressionist art to create architectural projects with a conceptual edge. The hands at work weren’t always or only Matta-Clark’s – my image shows him working with Gerry Hovagimyan on “Conical Intersect,” a project realized in Paris in 1975.   But there was always an off-the-cuff, improvisatory quality to what he did.

Wouldn’t it be exciting to hand a chainsaw, an ax and a level to Frank Gehry or Renzo Piano, and charge them with a single task: Build. (Photo by Harry Gruyaert / Courtesy 2017 Estate of Gordon Matta-Clark / Artists Rights Society (ARS), New York and David Zwirner, New York)

posts.caption:
MICHELANGELO’S EMBARRASSMENT OF RICHES

THE WEEKLY PIC: The highest praise I can give to any museum exhibition is to say that it undoes the old clichés on its subject. After a couple of visits to “Michelangelo: Divine Draftsman and Designer,” the drawings show that wraps up this week at the Metropolitan Museum in New York, I’ve got a whole new view of the master.  Forget the old idea of Michelangelo as a heroic genius whose monumental vision of the human form replaced earlier gracilities. (Art history’s tag line for that old view?: “Manly yes, but I like it too.”)

In the Met show, I was blown away by Michelangelo’s ornamental imperative. Almost every drawing is covered in a welter of lines and shapes and stories whose overall decorative effect is as potent as its individual moments of virile vision. The more a drawing seems to be finished and important – a gift, maybe, to a patron or crush – the more it has going on within its borders. We tend to think of draftsmen as constantly paring back from their first thoughts, as finding order and form in chaos. But with Michelangelo there’s often more addition than erasure. He’s often more concerned with fleshing-out a slight first idea than with finding his way to pared-down essentials.

My sense is that art history has concentrated on the local machismo in Michelangelo’s drawings – a gorgeous torso here, a stunning biceps there – at the expense of a much more delicate, ornamental totality. We’ve worked hard to turn Michelangelo’s art into something more palatable to our bold modern tastes, trained to see ornament as criminally weak.

At the Met, I was reminded that even the clean, confident contours and forms that we admire so much in Michelangelo’s sculptures were originally meant to play off against, and be tempered by, a framework of elaborate architectural ornament. DOUGLAS GORDON, THE SIX-EYED RAVEN?

THE WEEKLY PIC: Douglas Gordon is probably best known as a maker of art that wows, but beneath the spectacle of his best work there’s an artist who simply looks. What is his great “24 Hour Psycho,” after all, other than a frame-by-frame gaze at Hitchcock’s film? Today’s Pic is another fine example of Gordon the Watcher. It’s a three-monitor installation from 2008 called “Looking Down With His Black, Black Ee,” and it’s part of the micro-retrospective of Gordon’s work now at Gagosian in Chelsea in New York. (Click on my image to watch a clip.)

All Gordon has done is to record the behavior of a bunch of ravens around a church in France, and to let us see the results of that observation. It makes Bruce Nauman’s videos of his cat seem almost Baroque.

A statement on the piece, keen maybe to add a dash of spectacle to our reading of it, sees the birds as  “a symbol of menace” and the videos as exploring “film’s ability to elicit fear.” But I have to say that I had a much more prosaic take. There’s been a lot of talk, lately, of the astounding intelligence of crows, and how much that makes them resemble us humans. Which made “Looking Down With His Black, Black Ee” feel a bit like staring in the mirror. The ravens strutting and cawing in the empty forecourt of their church did a pretty good impersonation of what we gallerygoers were doing at Gagosian. (© Studio lost but found/VG Bild-Kunst, Bonn 2018; photo by Rob McKeever, courtesy Gagosian)

Warhol and Thurber: Dream Team or Odd Couple?

THE WEEKLY PIC: For a while we’ve known – or had hints ­– that Andy Warhol had, improbably, worked on costumes for a Broadway show based on work by the New Yorker writer and cartoonist James Thurber. Or at least, Warhol’s diaries pointed us both to the play and away from it at the same time, claiming that he didn’t get credit for his work “because of the union. In 1954 or ’55. I guess I was exploited.” Whereas in fact the show in question was a 1963 musical called “The Beast in Me,” based on fables written by Thurber, who had recently died and was much mourned. Today’s Pic shows one of many images of the production which I unearthed at the New York Public Library, from the archives of the photo studio once run by Leo and Sy Friedman and Joseph Abeles.

The costumes show Warhol taking a break from the tough radicalism of his most recent Pop Art and stepping back into the theatrical work he’d toyed with in college and then in the ’50s – and that he showed an interest in for the rest of his life. An actress he’d admired for her soap-opera work had launched the project, and since Warhol had long known and admired Thurber’s art – in the 1940s he’d owned a volume of Thurber fables and certain of his ’50s illustrations of bunnies came close to copying it – he agreed to do costumes for the show. He had other connections to it, anyway: Its choreography was by his 1950s friend (and crush) John Butler and it starred an actress from his long-favorite musical The Golden Apple.

Warhol came up with a clever design idea that, for the first time in his theatrical work, broke away from the comfortable ’50s stylings that he’d still been using for the stage even a couple of years earlier. Since Thurber’s cartoons were nothing more than loopy outline drawings that made all his figures look like rag dolls, Warhol tried for the same effect: He dressed his actors in one-piece white Dr. Denton pajamas, to which he added accessories, as needed, to flesh out their parts in each scene. “Well, it was all very creative,” recalled one of the actresses, “but everything was attached with Velcro: There were little pieces of fabric everywhere.”

Warhol didn’t go uncredited, as he claimed, but because he was not a member of the Scenic Artists union – his archives show him toying with taking the admissions test, but coming to the idea too late – the show’s program could only give him an almost invisible credit for “costume concept.” (See below.)

That bottom billing was just as well. After insanely last-minute casting, re-writes and rehearsals, plus a postponed premiere, the show got lukewarm reviews (the costumes were said to be “tasteful” and “attractive”) and closed after only four nights. “Oh dear, failure is always so sordid,” wrote the producer, as she and Warhol haggled over his payment for the flop. One critic who was a fan of the “charming and pleasant” show wrote an essay blaming its failure on the culture’s new taste for novelty and extremism, ironic given the avant-gardist ideals of the Pop artist who did its costumes. (Friedman-Abeles photograph collection, Billy Rose Theatre Division, New York Public Library)

THE WEEKLY PIC: When first I saw “Access+Ability,” the wonderful show about new designs for the disabled now at the Cooper-Hewitt museum in New York, I was especially fascinated by this set of three “Chatfield Walking Canes” by Matthew Kroeker. We can all imagine ourselves someday needing to walk with a stick, and it was nice to know that esthetics might be part of the equation. Then when I tested the canes in the museum gift shop, I realized that their function was as good as their look.

But I have to say that I only fully recognized the importance of those canes – of any device that assists the disabled – this past weekend as I watched a dance event called “The Way You Look (at me) Tonight,” staged by Claire Cunningham and Jess Curtis as part of the American Realness festival in New York. posts.caption:
THE WEEKLY PIC: Jason Rhoades always believed that too much was never enough. In the vast plenitude of objects that make up his current show at the Brant Foundation in Connecticut, my eyes kept going back to the collaged photos that surround the installation called “My Brother/Brancuzi,” where Rhoades pairs classic shots of the studio of Constantin Brancusi with un-classic ones of his brother’s suburban bedroom.

One thing I admire about Rhoades is that he’s willing to poke fun at every established idea, to pick away at every scabby cliché. The juxtapositions in this photography series, for instance, undermine the romantic idea that the artist’s studio is a magical space unlike any other. In Rhoades’s hands, it doesn’t seem much more magicked than his brother’s room. They also undermine the stale idea that, looked at correctly, everyday spaces and objects are as powerful a source of esthetics as anything that’s born in the art world. Sorry, Brancusi’s sculptures beat out that flat screen, any day.

One final thing: Looking at Rhoades’s photos, somewhere in the back of your mind you get the sense that he really does believe in studio magic, and also in the glories of his brother’s wall-to-wall. (Photo by Sean Keenan, courtesy of The Brant Foundation)
